page.title: 06Local Agriculture
page.content: Farming in this part of Suffolk is mainly arable,producing wheat,barley, oilseed rape and oats,with some peas, beans and potatoes.There are a few beef cattle,pigs and poultry. Small farms have been absorbed into large holdings: small fields have become larger by removal of boundary hedges,to give easier access for today's huge machinery.Conservationists are pressing farmers to reintroduce hedges and woods;the natural habitat of many plant and animal species at present in decline.Concern is also being expressed about methods used to increase yields, particularly the use of chemicals and the consequent increase of nitrates in the soil and ultimately in the water supply.Farming is no longer labour- intensive,few local people rely on it as a source of income,though all benefit from increased food production.
